x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement: Though there's a growing interest among Nigerian women to enter technology (coding, ServiceNow, data, cloud), mentorship, structured learning paths, exposure to projects, and networking are often ad hoc. There is no unified, data-driven platform to register mentorship, track skill acquisition, manage learning outcomes, or connect with corporate opportunities. Beginners get lost; organizations duplicate efforts; female talent is under-leveraged.

x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.solution_proposal:
How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

SheTech Connect would be a holistic learning & mentorship ecosystem:

  • App Engine Studio: user profiles (mentors, mentees), learning module catalog, skill goals, and assessment logs.
  • SPM / Strategic Portfolio Management: for planning learning portfolios, scheduling courses, and tracking progress over time, especially useful for enterprises wanting to partner or sponsor.
  • Virtual Agent / GenAI: for automated Q&A (“Which learning path is good for me?” and “Suggest local workshops”), maybe adaptive suggestions.
  • Flow Designer: matching algorithm for mentors and mentees based on skills, location, and availability; automated scheduling; reminders.
  • IntegrationHub: link with external course providers (Udemy, Coursera, LinkedIn Learning) to pull course metadata, maybe certifications, and also job boards.
  • Performance Analytics: dashboards for how many women have taken courses and completed them and how many internships/jobs they move into; gender parity metrics.

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

Course provider APIs (or at least metadata), Email/SMS/WhatsApp gateway for notifications, and secure identity and profile management will be needed.

Gamification/reward systems (badges, certificates) and local community event integration are dependable but optional.

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

  • Maintaining mentor availability & quality: mentors might drop off; ensuring mentor commitment; vetting.
  • Motivating mentees: avoiding early dropout; ensuring meaningful projects.
  • Digital divide: many women may not have reliable internet or devices; they need mobile-friendly and low-bandwidth options.
  • Localization: content might need local context; offer in local languages; reflect Nigeria’s tech job market.
